text: When people speak about languages that have gender, they tend to think that the object has the gender, but it's not the object, it's the word.

text: Now, where you use the formal language and the informal language really, really depends on the dialect.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So the safe way is to go in with the formal and to see what happens, and to see how people address you, and see how people address each other in this context, and you can adjust accordingly.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, in Spain, when you meet somebody, when you're going to a shop, when you meet somebody for the first time, with the exception of kind of young peers, the common thing is to begin speaking formally.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If I compare this to Buenos Aires, for example, in Argentina, it's almost never used this formal way of addressing people.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In fact, it's used more often to insult somebody with an extra layer of sarcasm or irony, let's say, than it's actually used sincerely to be formal.

text: So it really depends on the place.
